author: lightclient
content:
Re fork rollout: I've summarized some of the comments made back in Feb that motivated the new process doc

* arbitrum chains have 30d+ governance process, given these upgrade delays, the code needs to be ready *before* the upgrade is proposed, therefore the time between testnet releases and scheduling of mainnet is the main integration time that teams have. https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1334929278722248847, https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1336982987090165770
* L2s need to ensure their systems continue work with new L1 features, regardless if the L2 env upgrades then or not. This often necessitates upgrades to L1 contracts / other tooling. Plus, many apps have 30d upgrade policies anyways. https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1335008059323580416
* stage 2 rollups generally require ~30d upgrade delay, L1 should promote that not penalize over it https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1335075922704863324
* light clients for ethereum L1 on other chains often require ~30d upgrade delays https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1333874991518973952

I don't see how any of these statements could have meaningfully changed over the past 6 months, so there is no reason to deviate from the process we agreed on. If 30d is the recommended stage 2 delay period, then we _must_ given L2s time before the fork to digest and make any changes necessary using the released code. L1 should be a role model for the ecosystem, consistently shipping quality forks with reasonable timing for downstream consumers to digest and update.

In the grand scheme of things, a few months will not make or break ethereum. But one rushed fork could.

author: timbeiko
content:
Thank you for compiling this! I was also going back into the ACD archives trying to understand how we got to this decision. 

We formally agreed to the process on ACDE#208. On the call, there were already concerns raised about the delays from the testnet scheduling part of this process, but we decided to "take that async", which doesn't seem to have happened. The relevant section is from about [10:30 to 13:50](https://www.youtube.com/live/0eVoE_isGBk?feature=shared&t=631)

Reading the threads you've linked, it's clear that everyone wants 30+days between a mainnet announcement and fork date, but it's less clear to me that this is strictly necessary for the first testnet fork? I think this may actually be worth digging into with teams more, to make sure we understand their constraints. 

From what I've read, I could see something like "testnets require a full 30 day cycle post announcement", rather than 30 days before the *first testnet fork* being sufficient, but I'd want to validate that.

author: lightclient
content: I think the point is that the 30d period from mainnet announcement to mainnet needed for the _governance_ delay, but the actual work to prepare the software for the governance proposal in the first place happens before that. So the 30d between testnet releases and testnet activiation is the time that teams prepare the software so they can participate in the testnet upgrades themselves and iron out any issues that may arise.

author: lightclient
content:
With the latest proposed timeline, there is 7d from release before launching holesky and 14d before launching sepolia. So not only do downstream teams need to drop whatever they are doing and grind on supporting the fork in 7d, they also can't actually schedule exactly when that 7d period is going to be because we will only decide when that window will be ~2 weeks before it happens.

But even if we did go with the 7d window, we're only shipping the fork ~3w earlier than if we followed the process. I think it is a weird point for us to spend so much time arguing about since we could save much more time if we focused instead on improving processes earlier on in the fork and minimizing the total number of devnet cycles.

author: potuz
content: They don't really have much of a saying, there are widely accepted limits of what an exit window should be and the notion of rollup stages is ingrained now. Asking rollups to give up a stage status because we want to ship a faster fork would be crazy. Having said so, this **only** applies to mainnet and not testnets so it's not an issue as far as I know in Fusaka's case so far.

author: timbeiko
content:
On the testnet point, I tried to find other instances of it coming up on ACD explicitly and there really aren't much. On [ACDE#216](https://www.youtube.com/live/dkIQxIHX56E?feature=shared&t=396), I brought up the release process to highlight that if we wanted to ship in November and follow it, we'd need testnet releases late August (basically now). 

The conversation shifted towards what we actually want to see before moving to testnets, and whether to change the scope of the fork, rather than an explicit discussion of the different timelines.

author: timbeiko
content:
I'm not saying we necessarily should change what's in the process doc, and agree that upstream improvements to the process can be much higher ROI than shaving off a few days at the end (though we are past that point for Fusaka). 

However, it's not clear to me that we ever made a super clear commitment to the specific numbers in that doc, especially for the testnet rollout delays. 

I don't think it's unreasonable to get more feedback from stakeholders about what they see as necessary delays for testnet upgrades so that we can anchor our timeline in actual security considerations, rather than dogmatically sticking to numbers that don't seem to have a strong rationale for them.
